/COMMIT_MSG.message: I disagree here. Currently we let all exceptions on api calls bubble up and catch them in _updateChange and reraise them in order to prevent operating on wrong data on changes. This change changes that and transforms an api error (which could be anything from access denied, bug in the graphql query or a 500) silently (for the user) into 'change cannot merge'. This makes zuul operating on wrong data instead of just not operating on the change due to the error (which I'd consider a safer fallback).

zuul/driver/github/graphql/__init__.py.message:
Should this check if status_code is not >=200 and not < 300 ? That way we handle other success responses.

I'm also not sure MergeFailure() is the right exception here as MergeFailure is used when merges actually fail, but this is just checking whether or not something is allowed to merge if I understand correctly.
Why not just using response.raise_for_status() here? This is a quite standard way and is used for most other calls as well.

I feel like anything !200 from graphql is going to cause a problem, so it might be useful to call it out explicitly.

Note that github.session.post does log things like (from attached story):

 POST https://api.github.com/graphql result: 401, size: 177, duration: 47, zuul_query: canmerge, owner: ansible, repo: ansible, pull: 74892, head_sha: 8d4bed1690e5baa023045384695ae86a101aec21

however it's fairly easy to mistake "result:" -- I certainly missed it although it's obvious once pointed out.  We should definitely stop loudly in that case.
I was thinking that a 201, 202, 203, 204, 205, or 206 may be possible and represent a valid return. Failing when <200 or >299 makes sense to me.

This comment seems at odds with the check above?

I'm also not sure MergeFailure() is the right exception here as MergeFailure is used when merges actually fail, but this is just checking whether or not something is allowed to merge if I understand correctly.

I guess I'm making a difference between the HTTP request and the graphql query in it.  An invalid syntax for example will return 200 but with errors in the response.

This is really from early debugging when I thought we were making the query correctly but getting back invalid data; as it turned out that was not the case.  If people feel strongly we could drop this bit; as I don't really expect we'd have invalid queries make it into the production code.

MergeFailure was an educated guess based on grepping what other drivers seemed to be raising.  I'll certainly take advice on another exception.  ConfigurationError didn't seem quite right either.

Indeed, graphql returns always 200 (I guess except 40x or 500). The error reason is part of the body in graphql. So it indeed makes sense to check both.

However MergeFailure feels wrong here and indicates a false issue regarding mergeability of a PR (where the error here indicates an issue with a generic api call towards github). Other places in the github driver just use Exception.
Re MergeFailure maybe ChangeQueryFailure or similar? I just made that up so may need to add it 😊

I think we want to keep things in line with the original implementation and retry for the time being, assuming there's a timeout internal to libvirt etc for the detach. I'll ask around about that.
OK. I will add retry loop for this case based on the current retry loop parameters (sleeps an retry counts)

There's not a timeout within libvirtd VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_ID_DEVICE_REMOVAL_FAILED looks like it's raised synchronously after a direct failure to detach the device so we should likely retry our detach request before seeing this raised.
As above, I assume there's an internal timeout within libvirtd so we'd need to ensure our own is above that and then I'd error out tbh.
As above, there isn't and we need to retry our request.
OK, we can adjust our timeout to libvirt's one
My understanding is that the events should only be emitted when both configs are updated now so we shouldn't technically need to always retry unless we see VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_ID_DEVICE_REMOVAL_FAILED.
As above, we need to retry until VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_ID_DEVICE_REMOVED and/or the device has been removed from both configs.

OK we also discussed things in IRC[1] based on Lee's above comments. So I'm summarizing here:

* the get_device_conf_func() we use to check if the device exists looks into the live domain as it uses XMLDesc(0)

* sync device not found in case of the domain both live and persistent should cause a retry with persistent=false if the device still exists in the domain

* sync device not found error in case there is no two domains should be treated as error

* async error with DeviceRemovalFailedEvent (VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_ID_DEVICE_REMOVAL_FAILED) should trigger a retry

* before we retry it is safe to check if the device is still exists in the domain with get_device_conf_func to see if we really have to retry.

* our async timeout should be bigger than the libivirt internal timeout



[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-01-13.log.html#t2021-01-13T08:49:43

I should really rewrite this comment :/ but the scenario I was trying to describe is one where the persistent config was successfully updated to remove the volume in the past, but the live config still has the volume showing as attached.

Removal of the volume from the persistent config always succeeds (unless it is not found/already detached). But the removal of the volume from the live config can be refused by the guest. We have had customer scenarios where they tried to detach a volume from an instance but there was some file open on the volume or other issue that prevented detach from the live config.

In this case, they will try to detach the volume at a later time (in a new, separate request). We need to make sure we handle this case, where if we detect a device not found for the persistent config when we call with persistent=True, we should not short-circuit and leave the method. We need to try again with persistent=False and live=True to try to detach from only the live config.

The old bug was that the customer became unable to ever detach the volume from the guest's live config if it was refused once in the past because the method used to short-circuit and return upon detecting the volume already detached from the persistent config.

Just summarizing discussion from IRC chat with Gibi, Lee (and DanPB on #virt, OFTC) on the event VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_ID_DEVICE_REMOVAL_FAILED:

- There's no libvirt timeout before that event is emitted; it's emitted once we hit the failure
- The said _REMOVAL_FAILED event is emitted when ACPI refuses the device unplug explicitly.
- However, if the guest OS is just slow or not responding, then we don't get the _REMOVAL_FAILED event.
- The _REMOVAL_FAILED event is an unconditional failure — i.e. no need to retry if we get this event

Based on the above, I agree w/ the logic Gibi suggested: If we the _REMOVAL_FAILED event, we fail;  if we get timeout, we retry; if we get a sync failure about device missing [i.e. VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING] then we retry with 'persistent=False'

I did some further tests by modifying this patch to see how libvirt behaves if the device detached from the persistent config independently from detached from the live config. 

In a simple scenario[1]:
1) if I detach from the live config first then I got an event as expected. Then I detach from the persistent config and no event is received. 

2) if I detach the persistent config first then no event, then detach from the live config and I get an event as expected.

In a more complex scenario[2] something weird happens:
1) if I detach form live first then no event and no error is reported, then I detach from the persistent config, no event, no error, then I detach from the live config again, and there I get an event as expected.

2) if I detach from the persistent first then I see when I saw in the simple scenario.

From this I assume:
* detaching only from the persistent config does not generate the event
* there is something unexpected in the complex scenario and maybe it is in the test so I have to dig deeper there.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/d76d371e1d81bc0e78afdeb23f7128ff2eae09f5/tempest/api/compute/volumes/test_attach_volume.py#L67
[2] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/3442eaf87919e6ec9809eb15bcc327e94984dbc5/tempest/api/compute/servers/test_server_rescue_negative.py#L136

So, here's more notes based on further chat with Peter Krempa and DanPB:

Peter: 

- The _REMOVAL_FAILED event is emitted in certain cases based on an ACPI event from the guest, so in that case the "timeout" will depend on how quickly the guest responds, bypassing the libvirt timeout.  
- And the error is fatal — but it's not for every device, this is just for memory devices IIRC But it's not for every device, this is just for memory devices (based on Peter's recollection).  And libvirt might extend it in some cases to other devices, but it was not wired up last time I've checked.

DanPB:

- Unplug is an async operation, so libvirt will wait a short while for completion, but then return leaving it in progress.
- Suggest to deal with live and inactive config separately: removing it [i.e. the device being unplugged] from inactive config will essentially always succeed.  
- I.e. issue a separate 'detachDevice' call for inactive config and separate one for the live unplug, so you know exactly which part worked and which didn't.  After issuing the  'detachDevice' for the live config, you can just wait for VIR_DOMAIN_EVENT_ID_DEVICE_REMOVED  instead of retrying.

FWIW, I agree with the deal separately w/ active vs. inactive; and avoid retry altogether, since unplug is fundamentally an asynchronous operation.

So your fix states that we should retry if libvirt reports "already in the process of unplug". 

In the new logic:

* if this is the detach from the persistent domain then we never retry. Therefore we can never hit the case when a detach is already ongoing from this domain.

* if this is the detach from the live domain then we can only hit the "already in the process of unplug" case if there was a previous detach attempt in the callers retry loop and there we timed out waiting for the libvirt event. Based on this and the fact that qemu reports that the detach is still ongoing, I think the code can assume that a libvirt event will be emitted eventually. Not because of the current detach attempt but because of the previous one. In case of a timeout in the previous attempt the caller stopped waiting for the event. So the code can return from here and the caller can start waiting for such event again. 

This also shows an almost race condition in the live detach case:
1) first detach attempt triggered the detach in libvirt and started waiting for the event
2) the driver timed out waiting for the event
3) the driver checked the domain and saw that the device is still attached so decided to retry
4) libvirt sent the detach event but the driver ignored it as nobody waited for it
5) the driver starts the next retry step and issues the detach to libvirt again. Then libvirt reports that the device is missing, the driver raises DeviceNotFound that the client ignores.

So I think I will simply return form here in case of "already in the process of unplug" is reported.

This parameter is pased to tmp_base_dir parameter in template and actually the parameter is used to [sensu]tmp_base_dir in collectd-sensubility.conf. Having consistent name should be better here than explaining its usage too much in detail, IMO.

The benefit of having 2 separate directory is to maintain different lifecycle of these two directories. Files under tmp_base_dir are temporary files and should be cleared up when booting up node if any stale file is left(for example because of sudden shutdown) and CentOS/RHEL do such initial clean up by default. I understand your concern but AFAIK the other software like systemd is using this directory and deleting files under /var/tmp is very wrong, I'd say...

I totally agree with placing workdir under /var/lib.

Not sure what you don't like on above. $checkdir is a name of variable holding either value of $tmp_base_dir or "${workdir}/checks". That is a new "temporary" directory for sensubility's check scripts. The path "${workdir}/scripts" is a path for user defined scripts which should be downloaded during deployment.

The reason why I moved the sensubility directory from /var/tmp to /var/lib is that 1) I did not see a point in separating sensubility's data in two different base directories and 2) /var/tmp/ based dir can be cleaned by third party software or manually by operator. In case of such cleanup the content in "$workdir/checks" is recreated by sensubility automagicaly, but content of "$workdir/scripts" is created by puppet during deployment and there is no way to recreate it other than stack update.

Thanks for your clarification. I agree with the current implementation based on what I understand from your explanation.

I still have some concern with inconsistency between checkdir here and tmp_base_dir in lower layer but check_dir is a local variable and is not exposed, so we can leave it now.

Hmm, yeah maybe I named the parameter in sensubility itself confusing way in the first place.

While the base dir is named tmp_base_dir, it is definitely not expected to be cleaned, nevertheless the sensubility survives such event. The directory contains one script per each check. So both checks and scripts contain script files and so the lifecycle is de-facto same. To mon mix those two types of scripts the two subdirectories were used.

Regarding new name. This is not a new name, but another configuration parameter on puppet side + denying configuration for sensubility's tmp_base_dir, to ensure that those two subdirectories will be located in the same base directory, which is by default /var/lib/collectd-sensubility.

tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/module_u.message:
When port values as provided as a string, cephadm fails to apply the generated spec: for instance, if we have something like:

    ---
    placement:
      hosts:
      - standalone
    service_id: grafana
    service_name: grafana
    service_type: grafana
    spec:
      port: '3100'

it will fail, because the port value is expected as an integer. For this reason, we're adding the normalize_spec function to the ceph_mkspec module in order to be able to prevent this kind of failures when ansible evaluates everything as a string.

By doing this, the resulting dictionary will be something like:

    ---
    placement:
      hosts:
      - standalone
    service_id: grafana
    service_name: grafana
    service_type: grafana
    spec:
      port: 3100

which is acceptable.
Yes, I remember our discussion about this. Makes sense to me. Thanks.

Further backports will inherit the correct nodeset which is relevant for that branch, so no need to add any nodeset tag.

Thanks for the answers Luigi! :)
So in that case it's even better, we don't need to change anything anywhere at all. Though I'm thinking whether a grenade job in victoria, where the upgrade is from ussuri-to-victoria, should use the older (thus ussuri's) nodeset. As I guess the upgrade usually happens like that:
1. upgrade openstack components, and then
2. upgrade the operating system
...or am I wrong with this concept?

plugins/modules/host_aggregate.py.message: maybe we should instead change default argument value?

Could you elaborate a bit more?

Do you mean where create_aggregate is called to ensure the aggregate does have a hosts parameter?

iirc:
  >> aggregate = {"hosts": None}
  >> print(aggregate.get("hosts", []))
  >> None

It won't work that way.
Maybe to change to:
  hosts_to_add = set(hosts) - set(aggregate.get("hosts") or [])

Thanks for reviewing my patch!

You example the aggregate does have a key "hosts" just with value None - that is just not the issue / bug I am trying to solve....

In the case of a newly created aggregate there simply is no key "hosts" (create_aggregate does not return it), and set() does require an iterable object, thus the error "TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable" (https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008925)


  >> aggregate = {"id": "idofmyaggregate", "name":"nameofmyaggregate"}
  >> print (aggregate)
  {'id': 'idofmyaggregate', 'name': 'nameofmyaggregate'}


1) object.get() happily does return an empty array as 'default':

  >> print (aggregate.get("hosts"))
  None
  >> print (aggregate.get("hosts", []))
  []


2) Receiving an empty array set will then produce an empty set:

 >> print (set(aggregate.get("hosts")))
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable

 >> print (set(aggregate.get("hosts", [])))
  set()



In any case, your suggestion would also allow for the key "hosts" to exist, but being of value None. This can either be considered to be more flexible in accepting input conditions, but at the same time is also less strict on allowed conditions ("hosts" key existing and not being an (empty) array at all).

You call, I gladly change this to your suggestion as it covers there initial bug as well.
Oh, I see what you mean, I thought it will be a "host" key always. In case it won't, your code is totally fine. Thanks for explanation.

plugins/module_utils/openstack.py.message:
Hi, Georgina, thanks for contribution!
I think linters won't like it. "is" and "is not" are to use with "None" mostly.
For checking for "True" just do:

  if module.params['validate_certs']:
  ...

For checking for "None":

  if module.params['validate_certs'] is None:
  ...

For checking for NOT "None" (True or False):

  if module.params['validate_certs'] is not None:
  ...

In your case I suppose you want just to check if it's True (value is non default and explicitly set), so first option will work for you:

  if module.params['validate_certs']:
  ...
That is such a silly mistake of me to make!! Thanks for reviewing.

bsp-files/kickstarts/post_kernel_aio_and.message: are we guaranteed that "norcu_cpulist" is not empty?   I'm looking at an AIO-DX lab running the regular load (not low-latency) and kthread_cpus is set to the whole cpu range, which means that norcu_cpulist is empty.

What you are seeing occurs for systemcontroller, eg,
subfunction=controller,worker
system_type=All-in-one
distributed_cloud_role=systemcontroller

The engineered configuration in that case is all logical cpu are platform, so that is why "irqaffinity=0-35 kthread_cpus=0-35" on that system you were looking at. The options with emypy map values such as "rcu_nocbs=" get dropped.

I believe this is correct, so with my change the "irqaffinity=" would be the new value on SC and dropped.  Installing a SC wouldn't hurt to verify.
Thanks for the extra info, that looks good.

In the case of installing AIO-DX as systemcontroller, the kickstart starts with the default AIO-DX kickstart values. After unlocking the controller, it has a newly calculated setting (from sysinv where kthread_cpus and irqaffinity are set the same where all cores are platform cores) and contain the full logical cpulist, the other empty lists like rcu_nocbs parameters are dropped.

vmware_nsx/services/lbaas/octavia/octavi.message: is Octavia serializing operations, or do we need to figure out what to do if a method is called before the timer for some other operation is called? In that case we should probably cancel all existing timers

Cancelling a timer is not an option as (a) our driver is stateless, so we cannot store the timer context and (b) the timer is initiated in o-api while the status is resolved in o-da. Octavia doesn't serialize operations so if there are consecutive updates within the timeout interval span, there is some risk (create, delete are irrelevant here). My assumption is that if consecutive updates were issued, they'll follow with consecutive updates via o-da and the final status will reflect the result of the latest update.

neutron/db/quota/driver_nolock.py.message: Does this driver imply REPEATABLE_READ isolation level?

No, this level of isolation is not needed. Just read committed isolation. The goal here is to calculate over a snapshot of (1) the resource table and (2) the reservations table. The sum of resources and reservations is the total number of used resources at this moment.

With read committed isolation, if two transactions are being executed, the second one can find double counted or missing rows [1]. That could lead to a quota overcommitment but that could also happen with the other driver.

I'll remove this comment because is not strictly true. This reservation method relies on the operation simplicity and speed, that reduces the concurrency with other transactions.

[1]https://sqlperformance.com/2014/04/t-sql-queries/the-read-committed-isolation-level

That's the same. "remove_reservation" is called from "commit_reservation" and "cancel_reservation" in the other driver too.

Actually, because "commit_reservation" is the same in "DbQuotaDriver", I'll remove it.

neutron/quota/resource.py.message: Please clarify what stops us from using CountableResource with new no-lock driver? Looking at class descriptions and all this "if not self._track_resource_events: return"s it feels CountableResource fits better.

"CountableResource" relies on a method to count the resources. "TrackedResource" relies on a DB model, on a resource table. To count the resources we query this table filtering by project_id.

Of course both are very similar but this difference is remarkable. I'm keeping this class because I want both drivers to be selectable and "TrackedResource" is used in many places of the Neutron code.

If, in a future, we decide to remove the old driver, we can refactor the Quota system, the classes and clean-up the quota API (we don't need the concept of "dirty" anymore).
